channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Welcomes Sanctions, While Russia Belittles Them
item.description: Ukrainian officials also said they would not scale back their military offensive, even if it impeded access by investigators to the crash site of a Malaysian airliner.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Pro-Russian separatists blocked observers from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe from reaching the crash site on Wednesday.

item.title: China and Uighurs Offer Differing Accounts of Violence in Xinjiang
item.description: Dozens died in what the official Chinese account described as a terrorist attack by Islamist extremists, but Uighur exile groups say was excessive police force against protesters.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: De Villiers May Gain an American Audience, Posthumously
item.description: Vintage will release English translations of the spy thrillers by Gérard de Villiers, the French novelist who died of cancer last fall.
item.dc:creator: By ALEXANDRA ALTER

item.title: Iraqi Anger Rises as Militants Attack Mosul’s Cultural History
item.description: Sunni extremists in Mosul have deemed historic sites, including tombs and shrines, heretical under Islamic law and have destroyed or plan to destroy them, leaving residents to mourn.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: People inspect the remnants of a revered Muslim shrine in Mosul that was destroyed by Sunni extremists.

item.title: Israeli Shells Said to Hit School in Gaza, Killing at Least 20
item.description: The United Nations-run school was serving as a shelter for Palestinians who fled attacks in other parts of Gaza.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Palestinians wounded during the shelling of a United Nations school in Gaza awaited treatment on Wednesday.

item.title: With Urbanization as Goal, China Moves to Change Registration Rules
item.description: China issued proposals to break down barriers between rural and urban residents that have long been seen as reinforcing inequality and hampering economic growth.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Migrant workers sleep inside a tunnel in Anhui Province. About 54 percent of Chinese people live in towns and cities, but only 36 percent are counted as urban residents under registration rules.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why French Politicians Appropriate Jean Jaurès
item.description: A certain idea of politics, one committed to an optimistic and generous understanding of France, seemed to die with Jean Jaurès.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT ZARETSKY
item.media:description: Jean Jaurès, the founder of France's Socialist Party, giving a speech on the outskirts of Paris in 1913.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Brazil's Unaffordable Homes
item.description: It's no wonder we're the country of favelas, and houses of cardboard and tin.
item.dc:creator: By VANESSA BARBARA

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Rwanda’s Unfinished Miracle
item.description: President Paul Kagame must set the country on a path that leads to a democratic transition.
item.dc:creator: By MURITHI MUTIGA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Spotlight Falls on China’s Former Security Chief
item.description: The investigation into Zhou Yongkang has provided an opportunity to question whether it is more about a clash of leaders than about corruption, and whether his fate could spell trouble for other retired officials.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Images of Zhou Yongkang, largely absent from state media since last year, are suddenly everywhere.

item.title: Lawmakers Voice Skepticism on Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: If an accord is reached, it would not be a formal treaty, so the Senate would not be called upon to ratify it.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: China’s Account of Bloodshed in Far West Is Disputed
item.description: State media said dozens were killed or wounded on Monday in a terror attack in the Xinjiang region, but exile groups said security forces had opened fire on protesters.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: World Briefing: Sierra Leone: Leading Doctor Dies of Ebola
item.description: The doctor leading Sierra Leone’s fight against the worst Ebola outbreak on record died from the virus on Tuesday, the country’s chief medical officer said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Rebels Explode Tunnels Under Aleppo
item.description: Insurgents fighting to oust President Bashar al-Assad detonated bomb-packed tunnels under buildings in the contested northern city of Aleppo on Tuesday, killing at least 13 soldiers and pro-government militiamen.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing : North Korea: Images Show Work on Rocket Site
item.description: North Korea has nearly completed construction of an improved site for launching long-range missiles and appears to have conducted multiple tests of rocket motors for them.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Body Is Found Above Plane’s Landing Gear
item.description: The Pentagon said Tuesday that members of the military at Ramstein Air Base in Germany had found the body of an adolescent male trapped above the landing gear of a C-130 aircraft after a trip to Africa.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Militants Overrun Base in Benghazi
item.description: Militant fighters overran a Libyan special forces base in the eastern city of Benghazi on Tuesday after a battle that killed at least 30 people.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Memo From South Africa: Honoring a Filmmaker in the Shadow of Apartheid
item.description: Although he did not oppose apartheid, Tonie van der Merwe created movies exclusively for blacks, launching the careers of many actors and technicians in the ’70s and ’80s.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Tonie van der Merwe receiving an award this month in Durban, South Africa, for his role in bringing black actors to the screen during apartheid.

item.title: As Sanctions Pile Up, Russians’ Alarm Grows Over Putin’s Tactics
item.description: Fears are growing that the festering turmoil in Ukraine and the new round of sanctions announced Tuesday will damage the economy to the extent that ordinary Russians feel it.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Critics are saying that President Vladimir V. Putin overreached by suggesting that Russia could thrive without the West.

item.title: U.S. Says Russia Tested Cruise Missile, Violating Treaty
item.description: The United States has concluded that Russia violated a landmark arms control treaty by testing a prohibited ground-launched cruise missile, according to senior American officials.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Sunday aboard a ship in Severomorsk, Russia.

item.title: Coordinated Sanctions Aim at Russia’s Ability to Tap Its Oil Reserves
item.description: The United States and Europe began a joint effort to curb Russia’s long-term ability to develop new oil resources, taking aim at a source of Kremlin power in retaliation for its intervention in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER, ALAN COWELL and JAMES KANTER

item.title: Loss of Shelter and Electricity Worsens a Crisis for Fleeing Gazans
item.description: Three weeks of war between Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza have pushed the territory to the brink of humanitarian disaster.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinian firefighters responded Tuesday to a blast at Gaza’s main power plant. The attack cut the electricity needed to pump water and sewage systems.

item.title: Israel Steps Up Airstrikes in Gaza as International Cease-Fire Efforts Stumble
item.description: A strike on the only electricity plant in Gaza threatened a deeper crisis, while diplomacy continued on many fronts.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and FARES AKRAM

item.title: Video of 2003 Kidnapping in Algeria
item.description: Rare video made by the militants behind a 2003 kidnapping of 32 Europeans shows the abductors smiling and waving for the camera as they ride their victims’ motorcycles.
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: In Reversal, Nepal to Allow Cremation of Tibetan Monk
item.description: The prime minister announced that he would allow the funeral of Shamar Rinpoche to take place in the country, reversing a decision seen by some as resulting from sensitivity to China.
item.dc:creator: By BHADRA SHARMA and GARDINER HARRIS
